data.title: LESS FEAR OF WAR.
data.meta_description: Broadly speaking, the news concerning the crisis in the Near East is reassuring, but a grave statement emanates from the London "Daily Express" to the effect that the Kemalists have already entered the netural zone near Chanak. ...
data.text:
RESTORING ALLIED UNITY.

FRENCH POLICY PACIFIC.

SANCTITY OF NEUTRAL ZONES.

HAS KEMAL PASHA TRESPASSED?

(Australian Press Association.)

Broadly speaking, (the news concerning the crisis in the Near East is re-

assuring, but a grave statement emanates from the London "Dally Express"

to the effect that the Kemalists have already entered the neutral zone near

Chanak.

The report that Kemal Pasha had given an undertaking to respect the

neutral zones was received with satisfaction in Downing street, and It is

understood that the British Government would be satisfied with this assurance

provided it were accompanied by adequate guarantees.

-? Should France and Italy both decide not to take part in the defence of

the neutral zones, thespritish Parliament would be summoned immediately.

Although it has again been declared that the French policy Is pacific.

It is stated in Paris that the French will not tolerate violation of the neutral

zones. French officials regard the outlook as distinctly brighter, and the visit

to Paris of Lords Curzon and Beatty is expected to ensure Allied unity.

ALARMING REPORT.

TURKS IN NEUTRAL ZONE.

French Withdraw from Chanak.

LONDON, Sept 20

The London Daily Express declares

that the Kemalists have entered the new

that zone near Chanak

News of the withdrawal of French troops

from Chanak has been confirmed The

force consisted of not more than 100

officers and men

Chanak is a fortified seaport on the eastern side

of ele- Darda Sellen at which Allied troops have

been landed 1

BAD NEWS UNCONFIRMED.

-s

No Word from Kemal Pasha.

Pans in Cheerful Mood

LONDON, Sept 20

Those in official circles in London have

not been informed of the report of a

Kemalist invasion of the neutral zone and

have as yet received no communication

from Ivcmal Pash It

is reported from Paris that the

British Note on the near eastern question

has created a good impression A spirit

of optimism has succeeded the almost tragic

anguish which ran through the press in

fact the newspapers interpret the British

Note as an indication of the fact that the

British Gov- crime. is desirous of returning

its troops in Asia Minor to the european

shore with the object of avoiding a possible

conflict with the Kemalists

The Petit Parisien predicting a peaceful

settlement of the trouble declares that

the public will not attempt to attack Con

santinople or Gallipoli before opening peace

pourparlers

LEADER'S~~UNDERTAKING.

Received with Satisfaction.

Would Suffice with Guarantees

LONDON, Sept 10

Cabinet resumed its deliberations this

morning Lord Beatty, Sir Hugh Trenchard

and Lord Cavan were again present

It is reported that the trench with

drawal of troops from Chanak came as a

surprise owing to the absence of official

confirmation of the news from Paris

Meanwhile, the report that Kemal Pasha

had given an undertaking to respect the

neutral zones has given satisfaction in

Downing street and it is understood that

the Government would be satisfied with

this assurance provided it were accom-

parnell by adequate guarantees There

will be no lighting if Kemal Pasha has

the power to prevent his troops from vi

during the neutral zones in Asia Minor

Cabinet decided that Lord Beatty should

proceed to Paris with the Foreign Secretary

(Lord Curzon) to interview M Pom

ence and possibly French naval experts I

regarding possible British measures Den a

nite decisions is hero reached by Cabinet

regarding the action which will be taken

in the event of an attempt to violate the

neutral zone

Lord Curzon has departed for Paris with

full instructions and Lord Beatty will

follow 1 mi

British Ministering agreed that any

movement of Kemnbst troops from the

Asiatic side could be effectively stopped

by naval action alone if necessary

No further meetings of the Cabinet have

been arranged and probably none will be

held until after I Lord Curzon s return

from Paris Sir Lloyd George has gone

to his country home

Declaration of Policy

An official statement issued from Downing,

street after the meeting of the Cabinet

says - It is stated in some news

papers that the semi-official declaration of

the policy issued on Saturdays is now regarded

by the Government as mistaken

this is untrue This declaration of policy

represented the decisions of the Cabinet

of the previous day and was issued with the

approval of all the Ministers then pre

sen in London in order that the public

throughout the Empire should not be left

in doubt regarding the aims and intentions

of the British Government on a critical J

question of Imperial policy in regard to

which the support of the Dominions was

invited The Cabinet is well satisfied with

the support accorded to it, not only in this

country out in the Dominions The *m

pire will not consent to sacrifice results

of the gallant struggle and decisive vic

tones of its sons in the Eastern theatre

It is reported that Italy) has decided to

send back to Constantinople the small son

tingent of Italians sent with the British

troops to the multi in zone

Should 1 lance and Italy deed not to

take part in the defence of the neutral

zone Parliament will immediately be summoned

.

Stock Exchange Improved

The improvement in the Near Eastern

outlook has had a good effect upon the

London Stock Exchange, and the tone is

better all round

labour Opposed to War

The Yorkshire textile workers have sent

a telegram to Mr Lloyd George, urging

that he should make use of the League of

Nations in the Near East crisis and stating

that Labour is opposed to all war

OPINION IN PARIS.

Outlook Distinctly Brighter.

Lord Curzon's Visit Timely

PARIS Sept 15

In official quarters the outlook in the

Near East is regarded as distinctly brighter,

in view of the decision of Great Britain to

send Lord Curzon and Lord Beatty to

interview M Poincare It is confidently

expected that the conference will speedily

result in the restoration of Allied unity

The British Foreign Minister (Lord

Curzon) will see- M Poincare on Wednesday,

but his arrival in Paris Ima already

created a better feeling

It is announced that although the French

Cabinet supported the withdrawal of French

troops from Chanak, it did so only because

of Kemal Pasha's assurance that he would

not attack Gallipoli

A high French authority states that if

Kemal Pasha places his foot within the

neutral zone it will not be talented Public

opinion is utterly hostile to military action

but a section of the public is asking if the"

British action is attributable to fuller in

formation than France possesses regarding

Soviet co-operation with the Kemalists

the French Cabinet has approved of the

instructions sent to day by the French

Prime Minister (M Poincare) to the

French diplomatic representatives in all the

Allied capitals confirming the decision that

France will follow a pacific policy in the

New Last

KEMALIST THREAT.

"Will occupy Chanak."

Neutral Zone not Recognised

PARIS, Sept 20

lend Bey, interviewed by a representa-

tic of the New York Herald declared

that the Kemalists intend to occupy

Chanak We do not recognise the neutral

zone on the Asiatic side he said

although recognising the Allied occupation

of Constantinople and Gallipoli If the

British wish to provoke trouble the blame

is theirs Turkey does not admit the right

of any nation to prohibit her from placing

troops anywhere on the Asiatic side of the

Straits When the Kemalists have occur

pied that side they will be willing to sit

at the peace table and even agree to an

Allied garrison at Gallipoli to protect the

Minorities If blood is to be shed it will

be Britain R fruit for her demands are

illogical If a conflagration breaks out it

will be very dangerous perhaps even fatal

to the British Empire

-?

Kemal Pasha's Movements

ATHENS Sept 10

Kemal Pasha has left Smyrna for Nico

needs near land south of Constantinople

in Asia Minor

Unholy Alliance Alleged.

Russia, Germany, and Turkey

WASHINGTON Sept 20

The Greek legation has issued what pin

1 forts to be the text of a treaty between

Russia Germany and Turkey which the

nation sty is the Greek Government ob-

tained at Constantinople from in Allied

h gallon The three countries name 1 in the

treaty agree to present a common front

to the enemy of any one of them and to

pursue a common foreign policy against any

nation acting arrogantly towards the

Powers defeated in the Great War Other

nations living common interests and with

territory contiguous to that of the three

Powers named, um join the alliance

whose members pledge themselves to give

each other favoured nation treatment

economically and not to lay down arms

until the national aspirations of each mem- ber

have been fully satisfied

Greek Troops Mutiny

ATHENS Sept 1

Mutinous G reel troops in Thrace seized

trains in order to repatriate them selves

Pro Turkish Demonstrations

CAIRO Sept 19

Persistent rumours current here that

Britain had definitely resumed hostilities

against the Turks have aroused enthusiastic

pro- tune ish demonstrations by portion if

the native population

TURKISH MASSACRES.

Further Atrocities Feared.

Christians Leaving Constantinople

LO\Sl\MI\01'LL Sept 19

An exodus of Christi was in anticipation

of a Ivemihst entry with a repetition of

the Smyrna. atrocities" has begun from this

city Thornlands of Greeks are beseiging

the Greek ( consulate to base then pass

ports v disc 1

Refugees from. Smyrna

fOVIX)*-, Sept

Representations made by the Allies

(jointly) to Kemal last, with a view to

(Greek ships being allowed to convey Greek

refugees from Smyrna have not been replied

to

Help from League of Nations

GI. NEVA Sept 19

the Assembly of the League of Nations

has adopted a report recommending that

Dr Nansen should be authorised to use

the services of the Russian refugee organ in

tion to assist in the relief of refugees from

the Near East Or Nansen has asked the

Council of the League to place at his disposal

if 100,000 gold francs with which to

begin the work until the League has time

to appeal to the public and to the Govern-

melons for funds

After having heard a represent alive of

1st imic interests the Assembly referred

to a commission a proposal to send a commissioner

to Asia Minor to inquire into the

latest massacres and to take measures to

prevent reprisals Persia intimated its

agreement that an inquiry should be

made A

America as Mediator.

To Avoid Another World War

NI WORK, Sept 19

in the United States house of Represen-

tatives Representative London (Now

Torr ) -introduced a motion requesting President

Harding to offer to mediate between

the nations fighting in the Near East He

declared that the European nations were

unable to settle the trouble because of conflicting

interests and jealousies and that

it was the duty of the United States to

assert its influence to avoid the development

of mother world war

"movincTITautiously."

Canada Wants Information.

OTTAWA, Sept 19

Although the Acting Premier of New

foundland has cabled to the British

Government that Newfoundland is ready

to assist against the Turks the Canadian

Cabinet is moving cautiously, and is sound

ing public opinion pending the receipt of

the additional information which the Imper-

il authorities have been asked to

supply

the western newspapers are demanding

full details of the situation in the belief

that the public will not Colour another

war unless proof is forthcoming that the

appeal stability nfineiiueed the W mm

peg Tribune for instance starts - It

is for Canada to decide if the British policy

is just and wise Should Parliament be

summoned to discuss the situation it is

probable that considerable opposition

could develop "

OTTAWA, Sept 10

Cabinet met again to-day, but no deed

sion was annnounced The Premier Mr

Mackenzie King) said that the first communique

received from Great Britain had

been more reassuring than the press reports

and had left much doubt in his

mind whether they would be any war at

all

Mr Tom Moore president of the Trades

and Labour Congress of Canada, conferred

with the Premier regarding labour's attitude

towards the Near East situation Mr Moore

declared that he concurred in the

attitude of the Government The time

had passed when the country should be

swept into war on a single declaration,

and without full investigation by the responsible

Government

South African Volunteers.

C WV TOWN, Sept 16

Although no official pronouncement hand

been forthcoming from the Government

! that troops will be sent, volunteers of good

type are already offering their services in

I Durban Port 1 Elizabeth, and elsewhere

The South African Nationalist press is

strongly against any participation in null

tary operations in the Near East

The Johannesburg drill hall has been

inundated by applicants for enrolment but

I notice was posted up stating that no re

a meeting had yet 16 en authorised

Graves of Gallipoli.

Sir Charles Harington impressed

LONDON, Sept 16

The British ( overridden in Chief of the

army of the Black Sea (Sir Charles Harting

ton), writing to the British High Commissioner

in Constantinople (Sir H Rumbold),

refers to the conclusions he formed during

a recent visit to Gallipoli He expresses

high appreciation of the work done there

by the Imperial War Graves Commission,

under the direction of Colonel Hughes, an

Australian Sir Charles was much im- pressed

by the really good and economical

organisation, was held, be says, st as most

pleasant to see

AUSTRALIA'S REPLY.

DISCLAIMER BY LABOUR PARTY.

Ministry's Policy Not Endorsed.

Mr I Labour party made it clear in the

House of Representatives yesterday that

the action of the Prime Minister (Mr

Hughes) in informing the Prime Minister

of Great Britain (Mr Lloyd George) that

the Ministry would be prepared, if circumstances

required, to send a contingent of

Australian troops to the Near East to cn

since the freedom of the Dardanelles and

the sanctity of the Gallipoli Peninsular,

did not have us endorsement

The question arose in consequence of a

newspaper headline over the report of the

debate in the House of Representatives

on Tuesday, which made it appear that

the Labour party had approved of the

action taken by Mr Hughes, the headline

leading, Government's Pledge Endorsed"

Hit leader of the Labour Opposition (Mr

Charlton) said that if he had understood

that the motion of Mr Hughes involved

the endorsement of the Ministry's policy

he would have if loved an amendment

The Assistant Minister for Repatriation

(Mr Lamond) -Mr- Hughes moved that

the statement he supplied to The Argus

on Sunday be printed

Labour Members-No

Mr Charlton Mr Hughes said - In

order to facilitate discussion I will move

that this paper (meaning the whole of

the Argus The printed

Mr Wise (V. sale said that part of

the paper containing his statement

the Assistant Minister for Defence (Sir

Grant die Rvne) -1 distinctly saw him

point to his statement in the newspaper

Mr ( Charlton said that he had made it

quite clear on tuesday that it was his intention

to move an amendment, which he

would have done had it not been for the

Prime Minister's statement that the House

would be consulted before it was actually

decided to send a contingent He now

asked Mr. Hughes if he had received a

cable message that d ty from Mr Lloyd

George giving full information regarding

the position in the Near Last and, if so,

if he would make it available to the

House

All Information Given

Mr Hughes I have received no cable

message conveying any information of any

kind other than the one I received on

Sunday I gave the whole of the infor-

mation contained in that message to the

House, although I did not read it word

for word, and I again ask the Leader of

the Opposition to come to my office and

see the message for himself Another

cable message came by ester is, I think,

but that was published in the newspapers

in extenso by Mr Lloyd George It had

reference to the satisfaction which existed

in Great Britain on the receipt of m for

tuition that the Commonwealth was prepared

to associate itself with the Imperial!

Government That exhausts all the in

formation that I have received from the

British Government, and no other m for

mutton has. been received other than by

win of despatches which are at least from

six to eight weeks old, and have no reference

whatever to the present position 1

ought to remind the Leader of the Opposition

in what I said yesterday in the

course of my speech, namely, that the British

Government has been asked to supply

full and precise information

Mr Anstey (V) asked Mr Hughes if

he had sent any communication to the

British Government based upon the proceedings

in the House

Mr Hughes sent a communication

yesterday after the inauguration of the

proceedings

Mr Brennan's Vigorous Effort |

Mr. Brennan (A ) who entered the

chamber life, Said that in a section of the

press it was murdered appear that the car

lying on the voices of the motion moved

in the Prime Afiniitor involved the cn

dorsement of what Air Hughes commutu

rated to the British Prime Minister As

far as he was concerned that entirely mis

represented his attitude

Labour Members-It misrepresents us

all

Air Brenn man while Mr Hughes was

speaking by a prodigious effort kept

silence but my feeling in regard to the

message of the Prime Minister was one

of intense amusement, faintly tinged with

contempt.

Mr. Anstey asked if Mr Hughes had

any objection to lay on the table a copy

of the message sent to Mr Lloyd George

Mr Hughes -It is not usual to lay such

messages on the table The honourable

member is acting very absurdly more ah

surdly than usual

Mr Anstey objected to Ali Hughes t

statement that he was acting absurdly

Mr Hughes -I w lady

Air McGrath (A 1 Will Air Hugh s

communicate to the House the purport of

the message he sent yesterday

Mr Hughes gave no answer

DISCUSSION IN SENATE

Bitter Speech by Senator Gardiner

Further reference to the views of the

Labour party in regard to the Near East

crisis was made in the Senate yesterday

by Senator Gardiner (N S W ) after the

Minister for Repatriation (Senator E D

Millen) had moved that the statement

communicated by the Prime Minister (Mr

Hughes) to the press on receipt of the

British Governments invitation to the

Dominions, be printed

Senator Gardiner said that the most

serious aspect of Mr Hughes s action was

that he had pledged Australia to wat

W.hile Parliament existed no such state

of affairs should be permitted There

were many reasons why Australia should

discourage the idea that she was at the

beck of the British Prime Minister -"Aub

train was carrying a burden that would

require all her care

Senator Elliott (V Could we have

avoided that'

Senator Gardiner -The question was

whether we could avoid a similar burden

in the future Parliament should have

discussed the matter before anything vi us

said to pledge Australia If to be true to

Australia was to be branded as disloyal to

Great Britain, then he was disloyal If

Australia did enter another war, -the

Ministry should pay off the old war debts

and pay as it went All incomes should

be limited to Â£300 and all amounts above

the maximum should be devoted to the

maintenance of the fighting men in the

area of war thousands of men had been

killed, and thousands put out of action

yet here we were eagerly looking forward

again- (Interruption and dissent )

A Senatorial whom are you speak

ing

Senator Gardiner -For those who supported

the Prime Minister when he

jumped in at the first w Jasper of war He

was speaking for Senator Cox, who, he

understood, had already volunteered his

sers ices

Senator Cox (N S W ) -Yea, and I am

proud of it (Hear, 1 car )

Senator Drake Brockman said that Senator

Gardiner's speech had been remarkable

(Hear, hear.) The first part of his

remarks had been his own thoughts, but

the second part had been prompted by

those who were Isohuid him, and they miss

represented the feelings of the workers of

Australia The present crisis struck at the

very root of the existence of the British

Empire and the white race (Hear,

hear Senator

Bakhap ( 1 ) referred to American

interests in Asia Minor, and expressed

the opinion that the United States would

betray a singular weakness if it were prepared

to allow American men and women

to be slaughtered, and American educational

institutions to be burned down

Senator MacDonald (Q ) supported Senator

Gardiner Senators De Largie (W A ),

Keating (T ), Payne (T ), Reid (Q New

land (SA), and Senior (SA) supported

the Men of the Ministry

Senator Elliott (V ) deprecated the

cessant preaching of class hatred, when it

was known that every section of the community

would come forward w llingly to

do its duty if the occasion anuo Hear,

hear)

Senator Guthrie (V 1, in strongly sup-

porting the Minister, said that it was

lamentable to have to contradict Senator

Gardiner's astounding statements and

sneering references

Approval was also expressed by Senators

Vardon (SA), Toll (t> ), Bolton (v ),

and Wilson (S A Senator

E D) Millen said that no Ministry

with a conception of its responsibilities,

faced with a crisis which required an

instant decision, would have been worth

its sitting it had not made up its mind

and trusted to the endorsement of Parliament

afterwards (Hear, hear.) The

motion was agreed to on the

voices

At 16 minutes past 1 o'clock the Senate

adjourned till this afternoon at 3 o'clock .
